meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Bozyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think it would be helpful for the rest of us too if we if if something comes up in the discussion that you think is particularly important that we want to report out on, make notes of it and then we can in the last 10 minutes I think we help um then with the sort of write up. Um so I think the other thing that they suggested which I think makes sense is in the first minute here is to take a look at that slide with the sort of um the prompts and and then um think about how you might want to respond to that and then we'll we'll start opening the discussion from there.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Bozyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: So why doesn't everyone do that right now?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Bozyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: All right, uh so I guess now everyone's had a chance to look through that. Um maybe I think the thing to do would be to uh open it up now and and have anyone who wants to start with a discussion on some of the sort of challenges associated with sort of imaging on a cellular scale and in complex biological networks. I know, you know, we just already talked about some of the organisms that people are working with. Um some more simple than others and where individual cells can already be tracked, but what do people see as some of the major hurdles and and major challenges that we have to overcome with imaging to be able to get to sort of the next level.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hey, I don't have that problem. I have resolution problem and sensitivity. I could I could image an elephant but not at cellular resolution. And so I think we keep getting stuck at those things where there's a a set amount of complexity and a fixed a certain amount of data we can collect and it's just a question of what scale and then connecting those scales seems to be the hard part. I love having convos with the cell biology people who are doing super resolution work and they're collecting data at the same at the same complexity I am, but they're just looking at one cell and meanwhile I'm looking at an entire brain and only getting 100 micron resolution. But I'm still faced with these these challenges.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I mean I feel you you've you've depth depth issues. I've um resolution issues. We're all we're all struggling.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah. So I mean that would raise up one uh potential um challenge which would be integrating data across modalities. Um so there are different modalities that can get different um different levels of resolution um at different scales. And so you could imagine if you had one system that you really want to understand, you could just apply all of them but you would need to have some way of integrating like the resulting data, right? Um you know, so you could imagine, you know, MRI down to fluorescence down to cryo um cryoEM. Um but then how do you actually integrate all those different data across scales into like a coherent picture um would be the would be the computational challenge.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: There's also a question of what is intelligible across scales. I remember having this this convo with um with Winford Dank who wants to do that. He wants to do cryoEM of an entire human brain even though it's going to take 10,000 years. And the question becomes well what does that what does um cryoEM level resolution give you when we're talking about macro scale connections and is that are some elements of that data not important and vice versa, like do do macro scale issues really affect um you know submicron scale um cellular connections. So some of it you you have to get rid of because you can't handle all that complexity and so what are the things you get what are the things you keep and what do you throw away as you switch between scales.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, it's a little bit the question of hypothesis driven research versus, you know, research for collecting information that can be used across maybe many hypotheses.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Bozyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: So what are some of the modalities that are you think most effective for these kinds of, you know, being able to span the scales that you're talking about, like imaging a whole brain versus imaging down to, you know, subcellular compartments.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: If you don't care about functional information.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: If you don't care about uh functional information, um cryoEM is a good is a good is a good modality. Um because you can it is hard and expensive, but you can get like the entire brain um with sufficient resolution to map out the the neuronal connections.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matthew Lovett-Barron
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think uh David brought up a really important point of using registration to bridge multiple types of microscopy or types of scales. I think that's really important and specifically with the brain this is something that, you know, I've been doing and other people have been doing where you can observe live brain activity and then take the same tissue and and either perform some sort of molecular labeling or do electron microscopy, tracing or something else that requires a fixed tissue, but if you're able to register this fixed tissue back to the live tissue at cellular resolution, then that that really allows you to combine all these things without having to find, you know, one method that fulfills all of your needs.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I I I do agree with Doug um in the sense that like at least to me like dynamics are the aspect of living systems that are the most interesting and I have a hard time believing that we're going to quote unquote understand um how these things work without having uh dynamic information. Um and yeah, I think that's a really um a substantial um a substantial challenge.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Doug Shepherd
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean, my question when when we talk about like so we, you know, we generate these huge tissue slabs of like human tissue as part of this cell atlas project, right? And we generate spatial omics data and it's like 40 terabytes and no one ever does anything with it. And then my question always is like this if you want to learn something about how the the network is functioning, then you need temporal data. So it's great to take all these, you know, huge maps and make these maps, but you know, I think there's a huge hole missing on the bigger, better, more resolution, which is like is it really that helpful to have that map if you don't know anything about what's going on inside of, you know, the network or doing these things. And so I I think for me I see a pathway to scale a lot of the imaging methods to to bigger samples, what I don't see is a a way to scale measuring things over time in the bigger samples at the moment where you have the resolution you need. I think that's a much bigger challenge personally for us at the moment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matthew Lovett-Barron
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think uh David brought up a really important point of using registration to bridge multiple types of microscopy or types of scales. I think that's really important and specifically with the brain this is something that, you know, I've been doing and other people have been doing where you can observe live brain activity and then take the same tissue and and either perform some sort of molecular labeling or do electron microscopy, tracing or something else that requires a fixed tissue, but if you're able to register this fixed tissue back to the live tissue at cellular resolution, then that that really allows you to combine all these things without having to find, you know, one method that fulfills all of your needs.
